It is impressive how these young divers jump so far down. We went at night and looks great. They really do very well.

We just froze when we saw these young boys going off these rock face, its a must to see, be aware thier timed shows, we walked up from the harbour when we berthed and only just managed to see the last of it!! I wouldn't walk again, easier to book a local taxi and go, they know

My friend took me here on my first day in Acapulco. It was pretty great. Heads up, there is a fee to enter the diving area. However, when I went it was open. So, make sure to call them, if they have a number, and find the hours of operation.
Young boys jumping from a cliff in a very narrow space into the sea. Soooo scary! If you do one thing in Acapulco, make it this one.
Quebrada is where you watch the best divers in the world as they jump on a sharp edged cliff to the delight of the crowd. Dangerous yet captivating
the food was very good an the service was great.very nice place watch the cliff divers. We enjoyed the view with a few drinks,
these guy's are the bravest entertainers you could, see. the lunch time show is amazing very hot. best to buy a drink or lunch and watch from the restaurant. great view.

Great experience! However do not fall for the tourist trap of eating at El Mirador hotel or any of the other restaurants surrounding La Quebrada. I've seen the day and night show and would definitely recommend doing the night show.

It was a nice experience to see the famouns Clavadistas. We went to a restaurant were we had a good view, it was very exiting to see them from soo close. Specialy after seeing the insane hight they jump from and how narrow it get !! if you have the possibility great experience !
Must see, enjoyed the divers speedy free form climbing to the dive platform. 40 peso fee per person.

If you have the time to go watch this it is a classic thing to do, this has been going on for many years and the views are stunning. This is a place you want to go when there is a sunset. If you are in Acapulco try to make the time to see this.

Went there on a boat with family and friends to watch the cliff divers jump. It's a very dangerous jump but these people are just fearless and have mastered it. Definitely a cool spot to stop for a drink and watch.

I have been to the cliff divers o many times that I have lost count. Will definitely go again in January, as my granddaughter (who has seen them) is coming to visit me in January with a friend that has never been here. It is very staged, but very dramatic and quite dangerous.
the divers were great, but the dinner was poor(airplane food at best) and not a venue you would book dinner and get a two selection menu of mass pre cooked fair
Really nice place, even they charge $20.00 pesos per person to see the guys jumping but it is really cool!!!
After a horrible food experience, we went down and went down to la quebrada. This place is awsome and beautiful, definetly recommended. They did have the attraction of the divers in to the ocean.

When you are in Acapulco don't miss this amazing experience! Not only the impressive show of the cliff divers but also the setting, the amazing view this place has to offer. The show ends at 8pm and it's very beautiful in the night. Entrance is 40 Pesos and a bunch of taxis are

This is a classic and a must visit while in Acapulco. You see the divers jump off the cliff in almost any movie made in Acapulco. It is a beautiful cliff and I still enjoy today watching the divers jump off into the sea. It's a must visit while in Acapulco.

The divers climb up the cliff and then they dive off the cliff. There were 5 divers and they all did different dives. You must see this show. It takes about 30 minutes. They climb up the cliff rather quickly and then they spend some time warming up . One by one they dive.

This is a must see in Acapulco! These guys are amazing!! We sat in the viewing area in the Hotel Mirador - for about ten dollars or less you get a national beverage of your choice and a great view of the divers. It is a great deal - better than than the 4 dollar platform down
Excellent - had a wonderful time watching the amazing cliff divers whilst in Acapulco. It's a must see whilst here
Best if seen from the ocean as you get a closer look but also can be seen from the Hotel. Incredible guys diving off the cliff from almost 40 meters up. A tradition in Acapulco for years.

Fantastic experience and one not to be missed. I have heard a lot about the brave boys from La Quebrada, but to see this in person is a fantastic experience. We booked seats in the "La Perla" restaurant, which offers the best "comfortable" views from your table. I would not

Sat at a restaurant called La Perla that over looked the "Quebrada" and watched the incredible diving that took place........wow, such brave and skilled young men. Later met them for a photo shoot with us. They were incredible better than I thought
we were on a cruise and one of the ports was Acapulco. It was incredible to watch the boys diving from the high cliffs. This is something not to miss and definitely doesn't disappoint!
we went on a city tour and saw these cliff divers, it was really amazing and I would recommend this for all tourists to see.
When I was a kid I used to watch cliff divers on Wide World of Sports. Now to actually be here in person, Wow

...and a great sunset view to boot!..., these men offer a great show, likely to never forget. 5 shows a day. We went at the 7:30pm one, and exceeded our expectations. Arrive early to choose a good spot.
This where the cliff divers dhow takes place. The divers climb up the cliffs like it is the thing to do and the dives are great!
Went to see the divers/jumpers, lasted for about half an hour, costed 40 peso to get a really good view! Super cool, well worth a visit!
Acceptable Looking nice to watch for one time Is better to stay inside the resturant But don't expect good food Usually one juice is fare

To me, the must thing to see in Acapulco. You can watch for free from different vantage points or you can pay a little and walk down the steps to get really up close and personal. If you eat at La Perla you can watch the show from the restaurant and then watch a later show down
The cliff divers were great! We sat inside with the 2-drink deal... didn't eat there. It was a great show, we were in the shade with a perfect view. A must-do if you are in Acapulco!
This is the most exciting thing I have seen in Mexico,maybe at all. You see different ages men jumping from a click.The story is interesting, the place-restaurant is nice, and the show is amazing.

This is another "must see" in Acapulco. These guys do an amazing work at cliff diving. You must be really passionate to do this or I imagine that it remains within a couple of families as a tradition. I saw a kid that did not look any older than 12 doing it. Good performance!
Recommended and impresive. It's is a big performance twice per day! It's a must in acapulco! Go earlier because it is very crowded

Wow what a spectacular show. You definitely need to arrive early because we went to the last show at 10:30 pm and the little ones can't see well because of the amount of crowd you pay 40 per adult and 25 per children.
In this attraction you see people jumping off a clief that is like 30 m tall it is a fasinating and exiting so you shouldn t miss it
It's a place to have a time to relax and look the beautiful scenario. There you can see the waves shocking on the rocks. It's very beautiful.
A spectacular show which now includes a woman diver as well. She is the daughter of one of the older cliff divers. It's one of a kind. The thrill of victory!!

This was one of the highlights of our trip. We were there for the first show of the day (near one o'clock) and it was great. I would imagine that it would be ever better at the sunset. The youngest diver that day was a nine year old. The entrance fee is forty pesos, and when you

I guess when you are in Acapylco you have to see this. It is quite amazing when you see those young men jumping down the cliffs. The full "show" is over after 15 minutes, but it is worth to see it. Entry fee is 40 pesos per person, so not a lot and in my opinion worth the money.

This is one of those iconic activities always shown when you see travel info about Acapulco. And it did not disappoint! It was exciting to watch the divers climb the rocks to the top, and you could feel the tension as they prepared themselves for the dives. A lot of fun.
The shows that these young men put on is totally awesome. From the smallest to the biggest, these young men do some of the best dives I have seen and off of the cliffs. Once again AWESOME!!!

It's a beautiful place to go walk and spend an evening. You can pay to see the divers jump from the cliffs up close or just watch from afar. There are many street vendors to buy food, drinks or souvenirs.

Our guide took us by here to see the show and eat lunch. Divers jump in on one side, swim across, then climb up 142 feet in nothing but a speedo, and then do flips, tricks, and dive back down in-between massive waves. Lunch is only $15 p/p American and includes one domestic
Enjoyed very much. we Watch the divers from the restaurant while eating A great lunch. Afterwords we were able to get pictures with the divers Highly recommend taking in this experience

I was there for 7 days staying at the crown Plaza A+ and my activities was to see Acapulco. So I went on a sea trip for 3 hours fantastic whith music a live performance, I discover The baie of Accapulco. After that I wnt chopping in Acapulco for souvenir what a great day I

La Quebrada is located in the Old Acapulco it is very easy to access by taxi. There is the public area where you 40 pesos and the restaurant La Perla. If you want to see the divers closer then the public area is the best, if you arrive early you have a great view. Now the

We watched the show at 730pm from Mirador restaurant. You could also choose to pay 40 pesos to stand at the podium just opposite the cliff where they jump. At the restaurant you pay more for drinks - 180 pesos for 2 drinks including entrance to view the jump. The view was

We watched the night divers show and it's a must thing to do when in Acapulco. We watched it from the La Perla restaurant and had a great dinner food (chicken fajitas were amazing). Mind you that there is a cover charge if you want to watch from the restaurant. It's $120 pesos

we went back the week after having been here 10 years ago its is very run down the restaurant was a ghost town no one eating there but a handful of people.it was pretty sad. the worst part is my order was given to me wrong 3 times!!! i sent it back showed him what i wanted point

We had a wonderful evening at La Perla watching the Acapulco divers. The cover charge is $120 pesos to get into the restaurant and for one drink. It's $180 if you want two drinks. There is a 3 course menu for about $400 pesos per person which includes the cover charge. We paid

As part of our city tour, we went to see the afternoon performance of the cliff divers. There is a restaurant on site and there are packages that include dinner and the evening performance. This without a doubt was the best part of our city tour. These young men are amazing to

It has the best views to see the show (clavadistas),but the food wasn't what I expected. First of all it was cold. We orderes the 3 course meal. And you would expect it to be the great, but its nothing special. It waa tasteless I didn't even finish it. Maybe order from the menu
This was one of my top 3 memories in Acapulco! 40 pesos to watch the show from the observatory; show is more than 10xs the value you pay !!! Enjoy ❤️🇮🇹🙏

We viewed the 1st afternoon session for the divers and were amazed and entertained. Had lunch at La Perla while viewing and as part of the city tour hosted by Sebastian Hernandez. Lunch was surprisingly good (shrimp tacos for the adults/burgers for the teens). Several flights of

We paid the $120 Pesos to have drinks and seating inside the La Perla restaurant and the view was perfect. For $40 Pesos you can walk down a long winding staircase and watch the divers up close but since my mom could not walk down all those stairs and back up we chose the the
This is a must do activity. We went for lunch and saw the divers from above, but the real show is later at night down below. It is amazing.
We enjoyed the divers show from the bottom of a long steep staircase, later moving halfway up for another angle. They have nerves of steel or are crazy.

Wow! These guys are unbelievable. We went to the 1 pm show and watched from the public viewing area. I'm glad we did not watch from La Perla since it's really quite far actually from where the divers enter the water. I think we paid @ $5 each and this was one of the best

My husband and I went for Dinner at La Quebrada the last night we were in Acapulco after two weeks vacationing there. The steak we ordered was very good. The show the Cliff divers gave was excellent. It was very romantic.

My understanding is that there is one daytime show. I went the other night and returned today to get better photos. I preferred the nighttime show but it was fun getting photos and meeting the divers!

We were brought here by family that live in Acapulco, so we knew this was going to be good before we even got there. Wow, we are so glad we went! Admission for the balcony (non-hotel) that the divers actually enter from is only 40 pesos for adults (cheaper for kids but I don't

The food was okay, but watching the cliff divers was amazing! By going in the daytime, I could really see them jump in the water, swim to the other side, climb the wall and prepare for their dives. Afterwards, they were eager to sign autographs and take pictures.
The cliff divers were amazing...what we could see. We were in the restaurant at night. The food was excellent!
Excellent show. Did the 1 PM show with lunch, ate at La Pearla. Great food great view. Get there early and get a good seat. You will not be disappointed.

Really enjoyed the Divers' Show. Short (about 15 minute show). Was very hot and there isn't any shade. Many stairs so if you have problems walking, I don't recommend you walk down the many many stairs.

Good place to stare at the sea, the show if the divers too. The shows are at 7pm, 8pm and 9pm. There is a small area full of small booths with vendors selling beautiful art pieces from clay dishes and monuments to food. And lots of taxis to take you back to your hotel.
Skip the "package" and order off the regular menu! Excellent service and we watched 2and a half diving shows.

We came to see a 1pm showing and arrived about 12.40pm and paid 40 pesos each to stand right across from the cliffs. It was hot and sunny and we wanted to keep our places at the front so didn't want to move to shade, so bring a hat and a drink! Watching the divers so closely was

We walked through the city to the headland where La Quebrada hosts the divers. We went to the 1pm dive which had about 5 divers, the youngest of whom was 15 years old, and had been training since he was 8 years old. I was very moved by the simple prayers the divers did before

The Acapulco Cliff Divers were the attraction on the first-ever episode of ABC's Wide World of Sports, 55 years ago. They are no less spectacular today. Personally, I find the barefoot climb up the cliff from the water more miraculous the the dive itself, and when you see these

We saw this as part of a city tour and although I was some what sceptical it ended up being very enjoyable. Our driver indicated he thinks the best viewing was from one of the restaurants at the top, and cool off a bit and have a nice lunch. The view was amazing and we also got
These people are amazing, I saw a kid jump of a cliff in the water. nothing but respect for these jumpers....

If you are not a sufferer of vertigo, you will really enjoy these divers making their cliff dives into the ocean swells below. They actually learn to time their jump and their impact with the rise and fall of the water that surges back and forth in the cove. Pretty amazing to

We traveled to see the cliff divers on day 3 of our trip and we were completely astounded by how agile the divers were climbing up the side of the cliffs to their diving positions and then how graceful the were actually diving. It was quite a site.
So much more impressive than watching it on a film or on TV, absolutely thrilling. There are lot of stairs to get right down to the bottom but we had a great view from near the top.
see the drives by day and night. get there early and pick your spot. skip the junk they sell and buy post cards of them in the air.
Very exciting to watch these young men climb up the rocks and dive into the writhing water! Very brave young men.
I enjoyed seeing the divers. If you've never been, it is definitely something to include in your plans. Once you've seen it, you probably won't need to see it again.
Nice lunch, great margarita, fun to watch the divers. Enjoyed the signature wall full of old Hollywood legends.
I visited this attraction several years ago, made very more famous by the Elvis film 'Fun in Acapulco. I am pleased I have seen this attraction, beautiful scenery & brave divers.
Went during the day, had refreshments in the restaurant, saw many divers, an amazing experience. Grandsons will never forget.

Arrive early and go to the restaurant right in front of La Quebrada to have a great view of the divers. The spectacle is great and amusing. Don't expect a fancy restaurant, it is very simple but quite enjoyable.

We saw the divers from the Mirador Hotel but when you see them from La Quebrada you realize how dangerous the dive really is. The divers earn their living from the entrance fee, so please do not begrudge them this money.
That 's an amazing show The guys jump from a mountain to the beach. Incredible! The Night show is more beautiful !

This is one of those tourist attractions that is a must to see... everyone goes here on their visit to Acapulco. But with that said, it is overpriced, the lunch we ate while waiting for the "10 minute show" to begin was probably the worst meal we had while staying in Acapulco,
Had been many years ago and viewed by boat. Went by private car this trip at night. Lots and lots of stairs so keep that in mind if your just going to pay the $40 peso to view.
Be prepared to traverse a LOT of stairs unless you watch from the hotel. I'm glad we watched from the platform below, but I had to stop a couple of times to catch my breath!
We have seen the show at all times of the day and night. The best show is the last one, where they turn out all the lights and dive with torches. A must see if you are in Acapulco!!
We went about 1/2 way down and could gone all the way down but would still be down their because would not be able to make it back up

World famous cliff divers, had to see! We had to wait for some time in very hot temperatures for the divers to prepare but it was worth it. Divers are all ages and dive from various heights off the cliff face. There are two main viewing areas outside and also from the hotel. We

The best dive show is at 2130...they use torches. We ate at the Hotel mirador (optional) all tables have spectacular views. The meal was a prefixed 3 course menu, and saw two shows while we ate. Food is good but not delicious. Purchased an optional photo for 100 pesos and took

Worth the visit. Spectacular dives! Young men apparently train for years, starting with Olympic high fives in a pool. Beautiful cliff location. Interesting drive to the dive location through back streets of old Acapulco.

I went to La Quebrada as part of a shore excursion from Acapulco. We had seats in one of the local restaurants so the view was just perfect and we could wait in comfort for the show. The divers climb up the rock face with bare feet, pray and then take their turns diving off

I took a Peruvian friend to do "something you must do in Acapulco" Obvious choice La Quebrada. Over the years I have come to see the fearless divers that need to time their jump perfectly so the right depth is waiting for them when they reach the water surface. They must jump
I took my teenage kids and smal children (2-3 years old) everybody enjoyed the divers show. Dives start st 1 pm, 7 pm and 8. Prices 40 pesos adult, 20 kids.

How do you describe the amazing feat of scaling a rock face barefoot and then diving into the uncertain waters below?! Graceful, stunning, crazy! We ate at La Perla Restaurant and were able to just turn our chairs to see two complete well-lit evening shows. The 3-course meal

Day was hot so made standing there waiting for the divers a little uncomfortable. Views amazing. Lots of steps to get to the best spot to watch the divers. Diving show Okay. As soon as they hit the water they are up for tips..it's cool..they deserve them. Lots of hawkers around

Beautifully scenic and fun! Many steps down to get close to divers, or there are a few chairs under shade just a little way down the steps, near the toilets. Be sure to tip the divers - only the most experienced get wages from the entry fees. A fun excursion!
These young men put a show on worth seeing, every dive is worthy of seeing, they put themselves at risk every show ,one mistake would be fatal as there is no safety net.
Went to see the cliff divers as part of a Sunwing excursion. Great show!! Something I wanted to see all my life and wasn't dissapointed! Would recommend!

3 couples went to dinner and watch the cliff do version, we had a blast. We each had the pre-fix menu which included 3 courses for $25.00 each plus tip. It also included 2 drinks per person. Everyone's meals were excellent, the service was good and the divers were incredible.
Watching the cliff divers (we watched from the restaurant at the top of the cliff) is really a thrill. It's a short but impressive show.
A breath - taking experience. We loved it. Best at the night, with fire show. Be careful about pocket thief /sorry, don¨t know if it"s right in English/
Young boys dive a few hundred feet to the ocean below. They take their time to dive when the waves come into the passage way for their safety.

My husband and I loved this and were so glad we stopped off to see the clavadistas here in acapulco. We had lunch at the restaurant which included the viewing platform which others say is a rip off but the food was good and we had a great uncrowded viewing point. The place was
Visited here to watch the famous diver of Acapulco. Very reasonable for drinks and lunch and to watch the divers. Have to visit her if you are in Acapulco
Took a taxi from the hotel, $100 pesos, $40 pesos entrance fee, midweek night show is better, it is not crowded.
Amazing view, the diving show is spectacular. A must see while you are in Acapulco. You should definitely talk to the divers afterwards. Ask them how many injuries they've had.

Visited here as it was on my list of must see places, you cant visit Acapulco unless you do so ! Show was ok if a kittle drawn out , 45 minutes to see 5 divers is a little excessive. Divers where ok but nothing that impressive. Be warned, you will most likely be hassles to

I was always told you couldn't visit Acapulco without seeing the cliff diving. The divers were good however it was a little boring. The show was dragged out quite a lot with not much really happening. I am pleased that I went as it's a part of visiting Acapulco but I wouldn't go
This is fascinating, and it is amazing the precision with which they must dive. A must see while in Acapulco. We also ate lunch at the restaurant there, and it was delicious.
Cliff divers, great icecream, amazing view, weather, only 40 pesos to see the show. If you are in Acapulco you must come here.

Got to the viewing section at 12:50pm on a Sunday for the 1:15pm show. We were lucky to get a viewing spot. Better to get their early enough to be able to stand as close to the wall to see when the diver hits the water. Otherwise you will only be able to see from anywhere them
Have dinner at La Perla. Live music, good food and an excelent view of the cliff divers. Watching the divers at night is bretahtaking... simply a must.

It's a lot of waiting to see a half dozen dives. Certainly brave young men, but sort of like watching Evel Knievel. BTW, there is no need to go to the restaurant with their $15USD cover for two drinks. For 40 pesos (+50 peso tip to the divers), or $6, you can walk down, and

Second time seeing. First time in 2012, and it was a 20 minute performance. In January 2016, the performers jumped/dove only three times but it was a Wednesday night with only a few spectators.Watched both times from La Perla restaurant. Paid $30 pesos per person for entry,
If you are visiting Acapulco this is the attraction you must see! Impressive diving! Great iconic location

We chose to pay the extra money to eat in the restaurant and watch the show from that vantage point. We ordered 10 minutes before the show was to begin. The diving did not begin until 30 minutes later. We enjoyed the diving experience, but the service at the restaurant was
A real show, difficult to find in the city! The swimmers are amazing! The place is a little bit old fashioned.

Thé best place to Watch the show is at the restaurant facing the cliff. For 220 pesos you can have a lunch ( fish is very good ) and a drink and see the divers. Go during the week for the 1 o'clock show. That way you get first row.
This has always been a highkight of Acapulco. The skill of these divers, who have been training from very young age, is amazing

I have been to This location three ways... The first from the belvedere, the second by boat, the third the restaurant La Perla! All three experiences were worth it. From the belvedere, the divers walk by you, cute guys... From the boat, they swim to you for money, cute guys but

Been many times. Been in the day and at night. I prefer day as you can see more. At night they dive with the torches. Take house guests when they visit. Unbelievable how they do what they do--and only for tips.

really interesting place. It is good to see once but not twice. you need to cab it there and back. I is located in the older part of town and caution should be used. go at night. You pay an admission fee, but the ticket is worth a beverage. the divers meet you at the end

This is definitely a MUST attraction when visiting Acapulco!!! The divers put on an amazing show day and night!! I do recommend going in the even, it's beautiful and of course less hot;)!! Great family event. You should GO!!
Amazing show....simply incredible. Daring divers will take ur breath away. You cannot visit Acapulco without going to the Quebrada. Elvis Prestley filmed 'fun in Acapulco' there!

We took a tour from our hotel to view the diving. While it was an amazing display of talent and daring it was not worth paying the $15 usd we paid to have a seat at the hotel and watch. They said it was a 30 minute show. Well, they dived six times in all. Again, amazing but

This is another attraction that have decades in Acapulco, if you don't visit it is like you never been here! These guys climbed all the way to the top to dive; they just follow theirs senses to see when is the right time to jump, if they make a small mistake can died instantly!

Ticket price 40 pesos each. We were able to stand in the handicap area as there were few people. This area has an excellent view without the stairs but maybe not always available. The parking was filled and we were happy we took a taxi.
This is a good place to visit during your stay in Acapulco. It is always impressive both the place and how brave the divers are.
Acapulco is mostly visited by Mexican people, some Americans because a lot are worried about safety. Perfectly save resort, particular if you stay in hotels at the edge of the city.

We sat in the restaurant at the cliff, great view spot! We had some drinks while waiting for the divers to start. I really enjoyed it! it was crazy! the water was anything but calm! they had to time their jumps to avoid injury! As we left the restaurant the divers young and
The diving show is quite short so don't be late. The diving is very impressive, but I was amazed at how fast they can climb up the cliffs. Be prepared to give them a few pesos, they deserve it.

It is definitely a must do, but don't expect a big show. 5 to 10 divers (young and old, skinny and fat) climb the ledge and perform the dangerous dive. It's a great tradition and worth while. There are many "shows" during the day, so pick one according to your itinerary and get
The men that dive from these cliffs are brave. The night dive is better to see as they really light the place up!
Awe inspiring show in a great location at the restaurant on the cliff. Price included two drinks, on the shaded balcony and the view was breath taking.
Very amazing. I wouldn't think of doing that, but I loved watching them. Sat in restaurant sipping virgin daiquiris. What fun!

Our driver Roberto Alarcon, got us the best seat in the house. The food at La Perla Restaurant was delicious. We had a few choices and we picked the fish fillet and it was delicious. We even got a picture with the cliff divers!
It is so fun to see how the little kids dive into the ocean! And the professionals al awesome! It is better than circ do solei
I came back to this fabulous place and still find it so interesting watching these guys making that dive.

To watch these guys is one of the only free things available in Acapulco. Well worth the visit. Athletic young men risking everything then climbing back up the rocks like Elvis. Chill, relax, enjoy. Then wonder if you could do it yourself.........................?
Going to La Quebrada is a must when in Acapulco. Very traditional feat from very brave men. You will continue to talk about this for days.
My wife appeared to be far more interested in the muscular toned fine young men diving , top effort and a thrilling site, tip generously please it's how they earn a living.
Very cool you have to do it. One afternoon show at 1pm. The show is pretty fast 30 minutes or so, don't be late.

The cliff jumping in Acapulco is a must-see! I have seen it both from the land, and from a boat at sea.In either case, these young people are in amazing physical form and will amaze you as they leap off the cliffs and scurry back up the rocks to go again!

The divers have been doing this for decades and it is definitely something to see in Acapulco. The daytime (1:30pm) show is more worthwhile than an evening shows (7:30pm and 8:30 pm), although we didn't go to the 10:30 finale where they dive with torches. Each show is
If you would like to see 4 to 6 men arrive by water and scale the rocks and then dive- this is definitely for you.
Very nice spot, with parking lot. The view area amazing. I wish I could jump from there like the native ones.

We watched from the hotel overlooking the divers - for 5 pesos you can buy a ticket to their patio and it comes with two drinks. The divers make almost all of their income from admission and tips - on the way out, they waited in their swimsuits to talk to visitors. It was worth
The drivers are unbelievable. There is a great viewing area/accommodation for people unable to walk down the steps. Divers are phenomenal!
6 Divers climb the rocks like goats before leaping off the rock face some 40 mtrs high and into only 4 mtrs deep water

The cliff diving itself is truly spectacular and even more impressive to see it live than in the many quintessential Acapulco promotional photos. The people who manage the venue as a tourist attraction really need to invest in a sound/light system from this century, but their

Without doubt the Acapulco Cliff Divers have been one of the most renowned attractions of that Mexican City and many of us remember those old Hollywood black- and-white movies where the protagonists are sitting at LA PERLA having their cocktails and watching the cliffdivers'
Our guide, Baldo Gomez made arrangements for us to have lunch and watch the cliff divers. The food was excellent at the restaurant where we sat to watch.
We went here for the 7.30pm cliff divers show which is a must see whilst in Acapulco. It is a lovely place in the evening and the divers are amazing

Even though it was not as spectacular in real life as it can be shown on TV or in movies, it was still impressive. Main dangers seem to be ensuring enough forward distance to clear the cliff face and only diving when the channel has enough water depth. Will leave it to them

We've been here several years ago to watch the cliff divers and were very impressed. It was just as spectacular this time around! They put on a very good show. The young men pray next to the little chapel on the cliff before each dive. At the end of the show, they come up to the
The show was amazing, I went to the 930 pm show and paid a little more to watch it from the restaurant; the view was amazing and so was the weather.

Lunch and show package is priced okay. Lunch was okay, service outstanding, and outdoor seating was very comfortable. We arrived an hour before show and got the best seat in house. If your don't order lunch you sit in the peanut gallery. Show was pretty good, but 25 minutes
A must see when in Acapulco! These young men are so brave and put on a wonderful show. Find out the times and get there early to get a better place to view.
Great iconic location. Excellent by day and night. Get there early and get a great spot. Or take a drink in the nearby hotel overlooking the cove. Awesome by day and magical by night.
When in Acapulco this is a must for every one,visited a while back.. It was fantastic to see these brave divers dive so far above the sea.
just do it! awesome spectacle, really worth the trip. we went to the lunch time show, not sure if the evening one would be more spectacular.... …

If you stand at the border of a 12 story building, you will feel what these divers may feel before jumping in to the abyss. Not for nothing La Quebrda divers are renown around the world, watching them jump of the cliff is a must see.
It was a sight to see. To jump off that cliff takes more guts than I will ever have....makes me wonder how they "work up to it".

Watching this is incredible because it's not only a matter of diving. You see these guys (I don't think they are older than 25) to climb this massive cliff Wall, and then just jump it like is a flight of stairs. You pay $30 pesos to park and $40 peson per person to go down to
the cliff divers are now young teens who dare jump from the cliff into the turbulent waters the cheaper way to watch the divers is from the view deck across from the cliff

La Quebrada a really beautiful exciting friendly world heritage site as per our evaluation - safe and secure for children- revealing!awesome! Be there for the scheduled dives - el mirador restaurant - exciting dining!

Old School Acapulco. Must see. Divers are pretty brave dudes. I ate at a restaurant that has views of the diving area. It was OK but did offer the best views. Don't forget to tip the divers. They surely won't forget to ask.

It was amazing watching the dives scale the rocks and then dive into the water. Boats from the ocean kept coming in too close to where the divers jump, so divers had to wait for them to move. Each diver, and there were six, only dove one time, so I was a little disappointed

Get there early and enjoy the show in the la perla restaurant.. thats the best way to see the show. I recommend the 10pm diving show because they have ^antorchas`^ with real fire as they dive into the ocean.
As most of the reviews said, it's a cheap car park, 3 minute walk down, you will find around 3 to 4 jumps and the boys that do it, do a great job

Very nice place to watch the Mexicans dive in very shallow water. Always many people there, good atmosphere....
This is a beautiful place to visit. The views are awesome and if your lucky you get to see the locals diving. Really nice place to visit but I won't be diving any time soon!!

This was part of a day long private tour. The vendor's are ferocious. Our driver was not allowed to stay but he sat us in the shade on stools. I was grateful for that. Some people walked down further but too hot for me. Our view was great. It just took a really long time

Went here to see the cliff divers, we chose to visit through the La Mirada hotel. you pay a small admission and get two drinks and a tableside view of the cove and divers. Bonus: the lower floor to the patio is covered in autographs and memorabilia of the famous celebs that have

stayed at the La Perla restaurant to watch this divers. It was a 10 US dollar entrance that comes with 1 free drink. There was a group of 8 divers, some of the divers were probably 9-10 years old, jumping from different levels. It was exciting and at the same time dangerous. But
Every traveler must go there. Is one of the coolest things to visit in Acapulco. Brave men jump from a really high height to the ocean and then they climb again in the rocks.

Legendary Quebrada! the view is amazing and the show is spectacular! This is one of the main reasons why so many travel to this paradise beach to see the young men sacrifie their lives as they dive into the beach from very high altitudes. Very impressing! A must!

I have had the yearning to see the divers for a long time, since I saw them on Wide World of Sport as a kid. There were 8 divers and without a doubt they are brave souls but I was left a bit hollow from the experience of the 'show' which lasted about 10 minutes. Worth having a
First time I've seen such show. Cliff diving...nightime!!! Thumbs up for the FEARLESS cliff divers of La Quebrada.

The divers are crazy! It was worth seeing once but so touristy and so many vendors following you and hitting you up to buy their goods; it was almost uncomfortable from that aspect. But unique still!
A beautiful spot to see what I had heard about for so many years. These are true athletes! We had a great lunch at the hotel while we watched.

My grandmother choose the hotel on the mountain for her honey moon, and I believe this place hasn't lost the charm. You will find here the clasical image of Acapulco, people diving from the mountain into the sea. An exciting thing to watch. Be aware there are many steps up and

I like it, it has been the same since I was a small kid, it is amazing to see those men jumping from the top rock counting the waves when the sea is higher so they don't hit down. Great athletes that start since childhood.
the show is definitely worth going to. the guys who dive from the cliff are definitely well trained and very brave. just watching them was scary, can't even imagine how they dive and stay calm:)
These are certainly brave lads and ladies. Watching them jump is really something. You can go in the afternoon and enjoy the sunset too.

Sure, its corny as hell, and feels like something out of a 50´s movie, but being there, and feeling the general vibe of awe after a daredevil jump from the cliff really makes one wonder... I mean, these people, the high divers come from generations of daredevils, that high dive

Find a seat by the edge of one of the restaurants and watch the divers. Area is touristy but this "show" has been going on for decades. Pretty impressive overall.

I was not impressed with La Quebrada.. and i will tell you why. wen we got there they sold us the seats to see it around $10 dlls per person. then at the end of the show they ask you for Tips $ 5 dlls more, and after before you get out form the area they DEMAND for Tips for the

We went there on our own,by taxi,we had a good position to see the divers,and it was very much interested to be there,the divers are young,and very professional specially when climbing the cliff and jumbing in the right time it is very amazing and a must to see that in Acapulco.

We found it hardly, but was our fault as walked from the hotel. The show was exciting maybe less what we expected. Very brave kids and people. Great experience, must go there if you are in this area.

When I was waiting there to see the divers preparing to jump from the cliffs - 40 to 80 ft high - and praying and waiting to the "right" wave to come, it's something that I cannot put into words. You have to SEE ! and uff, when they reach the water" UNIQUE! Unfortunately

It was more the hype than what went on. I guess I'm used to elaborated shows and this wasn't very attractive. I respect those who do the jumps, but I think they should include something to make it more amusing other than seeing people jump.
Long trip from Encanto by taxi, so expensive. Quebrada divers/restaurant and two drinks on top of that made it very expensive and food not more than one star.
I remember watch these dives as a kid on Wide World Of Sports. It was disappointing to see this in person. Nice way to take up a couple hours, the night diving was ever better.

One of the highlights of visiting Acapulco is the Cliff Divers At La Quebrada. They only dive at certain times of the day and they are not precise. We were there at the 1 PM show which actually took place at 1:35. However it was worth the wait. There is a viewing area far down

Very exciting to see the boys jump from the high cliffs. The restaurant was being remodeled and the rain kept us from sitting close to the railing, however, we were well accommodated toward the back of the patio. The view was excellent, however, it took the divers awhile to

Enjoy a GREAT meal and watch the cliff divers do their thing! It's a GREAT family evening attraction and the restaurant really is kid friendly even though it's higher end. Every time I visit I MUST see it!

Famous for many years, it is always a great spectacle, to see how this brave men and woman jump from the cliff in a narrow split in the coast. The best place to look at it, is from the terrace of the hotel, which once belonged to Mr. Teddy Stauffer, the famous band leader in the
First, kudos to those crazy enough to do this. It takes some big ones. Wish there would have been an announcer/MC We went at night and had dinner at La Perla. Service was outstanding, food sucked.

Absolutely amazing, great to be a part of such a wonderful experience. The Cliff Divers put on a spectacular show, a must see when you visit Acapulco.
Great place to enjoy even without the divers, especially at sunset. Good views of the whole city. The divers are a plus.

if you remember old Tarzan Movies you will enjoy the visit. the dives are very impressive, At the Mirador restaurant you will find wall with many Hollywood stars going back many decades. 154 steps to the bottom

text.wiki:
Acapulco de Juárez (Spanish: [akaˈpulko ðe ˈxwaɾes] (listen)), commonly called Acapulco ( AK-ə-PUUL-koh, also US:  AHK-), is a city and major seaport in the state of Guerrero on the Pacific coast of Mexico, 380 kilometres (240 mi) south of Mexico City. Acapulco is located on a deep, semicircular bay and has been a port since the early colonial period of Mexico's history. It is a port of call for shipping and cruise lines running between Panama and San Francisco, California, United States. The city of Acapulco is the largest in the state, far larger than the state capital Chilpancingo. Acapulco is also Mexico's largest beach and balneario resort city.The city is one of Mexico's oldest beach resorts, which came into prominence in the 1940s through the 1960s as a getaway for Hollywood stars and millionaires. Acapulco was once a popular tourist resort, but due to a massive upsurge in gang violence and murder since 2014 it no longer attracts many foreign tourists, and most now only come from Mexico itself. It is both the second deadliest city in Mexico and the second-deadliest city in the world; the US government has warned its citizens not to travel there. In 2016 there were 918 murders, and the homicide rate was one of the highest in the world: 103 in every 100,000. In September 2018 the city's entire police force was disarmed by the military, due to suspicions that it has been infiltrated by drug gangs.The resort area is divided into three parts: The north end of the bay and beyond is the "traditional" area, which encompasses the area from Parque Papagayo through the Zócalo and onto the beaches of Caleta and Caletilla, the main part of the bay known as "Zona Dorada" ('golden zone' in Spanish), where the famous in the mid-20th century vacationed, and the south end, "Diamante" ('diamond' in Spanish), which is dominated by newer luxury high-rise hotels and condominiums.
The name "Acapulco" comes from Nahuatl language Aca-pōl-co, and means "where the reeds were destroyed or washed away". The "de Juárez" was added to the official name in 1885 to honor Benito Juárez, former President of Mexico (1806–1872). The seal for the city shows broken reeds or cane. The island and municipality of Capul, in the Philippines, derives its name from Acapulco; Capul. Acapulco was the eastern end of the trans-Pacific sailing route from Acapulco to Manila, in what was then a Spanish colony.


== History ==


=== Pre-Columbian ===

By the 8th century around the Acapulco Bay area, there was a small culture which would first be dominated by the Olmecs, then by a number of others during the pre-Hispanic period before it ended in the 1520s. At Acapulco Bay itself, there were two Olmec sites, one by Playa Larga and the other on a hill known as El Guitarrón. Olmec influence caused the small spread-out villages here to coalesce into larger entities and build ceremonial centers.Later, Teotihuacan influence made its way here via Cuernavaca and Chilpancingo. Then Mayan influence arrived from the Isthmus of Tehuantepec and through what is now Oaxaca. This history is known through the archaeological artifacts that have been found here, especially at Playa Hornos, Pie de la Cuesta, and Tambuco.In the 11th century, new waves of migration of Nahuas and Coixas came through here. These people were the antecedents of the Aztecs. In the later 15th century, after four years of military struggle, Acapulco became part of the Aztec Empire during the reign of Ahuizotl (1486–1502). It was annexed to a tributary province named Tepecuacuilco. However, this was only transitory, as the Aztecs could only establish an unorganized military post at the city's outskirts. The city was in territory under control of the Yopes, who continued defending it and living there until the arrival of the Spanish in the 1520s.


=== 16th century ===

There are two stories about how Acapulco bay was discovered by Europeans. The first states that two years after the Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire, Hernán Cortés sent explorers west to find gold. The explorers had subdued this area after 1523, and Captain Saavedra Cerón was authorized by Cortés to found a settlement here. The other states that the bay was discovered on December 13, 1526 by a small ship named the El Tepache Santiago captained by Santiago Guevara.
The first encomendero was established in 1525 at Cacahuatepec, which is part of the modern Acapulco municipality. In 1531, a number of Spaniards, most notably Juan Rodriguez de Villafuerte, left the Oaxaca coast and founded the village of Villafuerte where the city of Acapulco now stands. Villafuerte was unable to subdue the local native peoples, and this eventually resulted in the Yopa Rebellion in the region of Cuautepec. Hernán Cortés was obligated to send Vasco Porcayo to negotiate with the indigenous people giving concessions. The province of Acapulco became the encomendero of Rodriguez de Villafuerte who received taxes in the form of cocoa, cotton and corn.Cortés established Acapulco as a major port by the early 1530s, with the first major road between Mexico City and the port constructed by 1531. The wharf, named Marqués, was constructed by 1533 between Bruja Point and Diamond Point. Soon after, the area was made an "alcadia" (major province or town).Spanish trade in the Far East would give Acapulco a prominent position in the economy of New Spain. In 1550 thirty Spanish families were sent to live here from Mexico City to have a permanent base of European residents. Galleons started arriving in Acapulco from Asia by 1565. Acapulco would become the second most important port, after Veracruz, due to its direct trade with the Philippines. This trade would focus on the yearly Manila-Acapulco Galleon trade, which was the nexus of all kinds of communications between New Spain, Europe and Asia. In 1573, the port was granted the monopoly of the Manila trade.


=== 17th–19th centuries ===

The galleon trade made its yearly run from the mid-16th century until the early 19th. The luxury items it brought to New Spain attracted the attention of English and Dutch pirates, such as Francis Drake, Henry Morgan and Thomas Cavendish, who called it "The Black Ship". A Dutch fleet invaded Acapulco in 1615, destroying much of the town before being driven off. The Fort of San Diego was built the following year to protect the port and the cargo of arriving ships. The fort was destroyed by an earthquake in 1776 and was rebuilt between 1778 and 1783.
At the beginning of the 19th century, King Charles IV declared Acapulco a Ciudad Official and it became an essential part of the Spanish Crown. However, not long after, the Mexican War of Independence began. In 1810, José María Morelos y Pavón attacked and burnt down the city, after he defeated royalist commander Francisco Parés at the Battle of Tres Palos. The independence of Mexico in 1821 ended the run of the Manila Galleon.
Acapulco's importance as a port recovered during the California Gold Rush in the mid-19th-century, with ships going to and coming from Panama stopping here. This city was the besieged on 19 April 1854 by Antonio López de Santa Anna after Guerrero's leadership had rebelled by issuing the Plan de Ayutla. After an unsuccessful week of fighting, Santa Anna retreated.


=== 20th century ===

In 1911, revolutionary forces took over the main plaza of Acapulco.
In 1920, the Prince of Wales (the future King Edward VIII) visited the area. Impressed by what he saw, he recommended the place to his compatriots in Europe, making it popular with the elite there. Much of the original hotel and trading infrastructure was built by a businessman named Albert B. Pullen from Corrigan, Texas, in the area now known as Old Acapulco. In 1933 Carlos Barnard started the first section of Hotel El Mirador, with 12 rooms on the cliffs of La Quebrada. Wolf Schoenborn purchased large amounts of undeveloped land and Albert Pullen built the Las Americas Hotel.In the mid-1940s, the first commercial wharf and warehouses were built. In the early 1950s, President Miguel Alemán Valdés upgraded the port's infrastructure, installing electrical lines, drainage systems, roads and the first highway to connect the port with Mexico City.
The economy grew and foreign investment increased with it. During the 1950s, Acapulco became the fashionable place for millionaire Hollywood stars such as Elizabeth Taylor, Frank Sinatra, Eddie Fisher and Brigitte Bardot. The 1963 Hollywood movie Fun in Acapulco, starring Elvis Presley, is set in Acapulco although the filming took place in the United States. Former swing musician Teddy Stauffer, the so-called "Mister Acapulco", was a hotel manager ("Villa Vera", "Casablanca"), who attracted many celebrities to Acapulco.From a population of only 4,000 or 5,000 in the 1940s, by the early 1960s, Acapulco had a population of about 50,000. In 1958, the Diocese of Acapulco was created by Pope Pius XII. It became an archdiocese in 1983.

During the 1960s and 1970s, new hotel resorts were built, and accommodation and transport were made cheaper. It was no longer necessary to be a millionaire to spend a holiday in Acapulco; the foreign and Mexican middle class could now afford to travel here. However, as more hotels were built in the south part of the bay, the old hotels of the 1950s lost their grandeur. For the 1968 Summer Olympics in neighboring Mexico City, Acapulco hosted the sailing (then yachting) events.
In the 1970s, there was a significant expansion of the port.The Miss Universe 1978 pageant took place in the city. In 1983, singer-songwriter Juan Gabriel wrote the song "Amor eterno", which pays homage to Acapulco. The song was first and most famously recorded by Rocio Durcal. Additionally, Acapulco is the hometown of actress, singer, and comedian Aída Pierce, who found fame during the 1980s, 1990s and the first decade of the 21st century.
The tollway known as the Ruta del Sol was built during the 1990s, crossing the mountains between Mexico City and Acapulco. The journey takes only about three-and-a-half hours, making Acapulco a favorite weekend destination for Mexico City inhabitants. It was in that time period that the economic impact of Acapulco as a tourist destination increased positively, and as a result new types of services emerged, such as the Colegio Nautilus. This educational project, backed by the state government, was created for the families of local and foreign investors and businessmen living in Acapulco who were in need of a bilingual and international education for their children.The port continued to grow and in 1996, a new private company, API Acapulco, was created to manage operations. This consolidated operations and now Acapulco is the major port for car exports to the Pacific.The city was devastated by Hurricane Pauline in 1997. The storm stranded tourists and left more than 100 dead in the city. Most of the victims were from the shantytowns built on steep hillsides that surround the city. Other victims were swept away by thirty-foot waves and 150 mph (240 km/h) winds. The main road, Avenida Costera, became a fast-moving river of sludge three feet in depth.


=== 21st century ===

In the 21st century, the Mexican Drug War has had a negative effect on tourism in Acapulco as rival drug traffickers fight each other for the Guerrero coast route that brings drugs from South America as well as soldiers that have been fighting the cartels since 2006.
A major gun battle between 18 gunmen and soldiers took place in the summer of 2009 in the Old Acapulco seaside area, lasting hours and killing 16 of the gunmen and two soldiers. This came after the swine flu outbreak earlier in the year nearly paralyzed the Mexican economy, forcing hotels to give discounts to bring tourists back. However, hotel occupancy for 2009 was down five percent from the year before. The death of Arturo Beltran Leyva in December 2009 resulted in infighting among different groups within the Beltran Leyva cartel.Gang violence continued to plague Acapulco through 2010 and into 2011, most notably with at least 15 dying in drug-related violence on March 13, 2010, and another 15 deaths on January 8, 2011. Among the first incident's dead were six members of the city police and the brother of an ex-mayor. In the second incident, the headless bodies of 15 young men were found dumped near the Plaza Sendero shopping center. On August 20, 2011, Mexican authorities reported that five headless bodies were found in Acapulco, three of which were placed in the city's main tourist area and two of which were cut into multiple pieces.On February 4, 2013, six Spanish men were tied up and robbed and the six Spanish women with them were gang-raped by five masked gunmen who stormed a beach house on the outskirts of Acapulco, though after these accusations, none of the victims decided to press charges. On September 28, 2014, Mexican politician Braulio Zaragoza was gunned down at the El Mirador hotel in the city. He was the leader of the conservative opposition National Action Party (PAN) in southern Guerrero state. Several politicians have been targeted by drug cartels operating in the area. Investigations are under way, but no arrests have yet been made. The insecurity due to individuals involved with drug cartels has cost the city of Acapulco its popularity among national and international tourists. It was stated by the Dirección General de Aeronáutica Civil that the number of international flyers coming to Acapulco decreased from 355,760 flyers registered in 2006 to 52,684 flyers in the year 2015, the number of international tourists flying to Acapulco dropped 85% in the interval of nine years.


== Geography and climate ==

The city, located on the Pacific coast of Mexico in the state of Guerrero, is classified as one of the state's seven regions, dividing the rest of the Guerrero coast into the Costa Grande and the Costa Chica. Forty percent of the municipality is mountainous terrain; another forty percent is semi-flat; and the other twenty percent is flat. Altitude varies from sea level to 1,699 metres (5,574 feet). The highest peaks are Potrero, San Nicolas, and Alto Camarón. One major river runs through the municipality, the Papagayo, along with a number of arroyos (streams). There are also two small lagoons, Tres Palos and Coyuca, along with a number of thermal springs.Acapulco features a tropical wet and dry climate (Köppen: Aw): hot with distinct wet and dry seasons, with more even temperatures between seasons than resorts farther north in Mexico, but this varies depending on altitude. The warmest areas are next to the sea where the city is. Tropical storms and hurricanes are threats from May through November. The forested area tends to lose leaves during the winter dry season, with evergreen pines in the highest elevations. Fauna consists mostly of deer, small mammals, a wide variety of both land and seabirds, and marine animals such as turtles. Oddly enough, January, its coolest month, also features its all-time record high.

The temperature of the sea is quite stable, with lows of 82 °F (28 °C) between January – March, and a high of 86 °F (30 °C) in August.


== Government ==

As the seat of a municipality, the city of Acapulco is the government authority for over 700 other communities, which together have a territory of 1,880.60 km2. This municipality borders the municipalities of Chilpancingo, Juan R Escudero (Tierra Colorada), San Marcos, Coyuca de Benítez with the Pacific Ocean to the south.
The metropolitan area is made up of the municipalities of Acapulco de Juárez and Coyuca de Benitez. The area has a population (as of 2005) of 786,830.


== Demographics ==


=== Population ===
Acapulco is the most populated city in the state of Guerrero, according to the results of the II Population and Housing Census 2010 carried out by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography (INEGI) with a census date of June 12, 2010, The city had until then a total population of 673 479 inhabitants, of that amount, 324 746 were men and 348 733 women. It is considered the twenty-second most populous city in Mexico and the tenth most populous metropolitan area in Mexico. It is also the city with the highest concentration of population of the homonymous municipality, representing 85.25 percent of the 789.971 inhabitants.The metropolitan area of Acapulco is made up of six towns in the municipality of Acapulco de Juárez and four in the municipality of Coyuca de Benítez. In agreement with the last count and official delimitation realized in 2010 altogether by the National Institute of Statistics and Geography, the National Council of Population and the Secretariat of Social Development, the metropolitan area of Acapulco grouped a total of 863 431 inhabitants in a surface of 3 538.5 km², which placed it as the tenth most populated district in Mexico. It is estimated according to a study by the National Autonomous University of Mexico on climate and geography, carried out in 2002, that between 2015 and 2020 the city of Acapulco will exceed one million inhabitants.

Notes
      Source: Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía 
      Population census (1895 - 1990, 2000 and 2010)
      Population Counts (1995 and 2005)


== Economy ==
Tourism is the main economic activity of the municipality and most of this is centered on Acapulco Bay. About seventy-three percent of the municipality's population is involved in commerce, most of it related to tourism and the port. Mining and manufacturing employ less than twenty percent and only about five percent is dedicated to agriculture. Industrial production is limited mostly to bottling, milk products, cement products, and ice and energy production. Agricultural products include tomatoes, corn, watermelon, beans, green chili peppers, and melons.


=== Tourism ===

Acapulco is one of Mexico's oldest coastal tourist destinations, reaching prominence in the 1950s as the place where Hollywood stars and millionaires vacationed on the beach in an exotic locale. In modern times, tourists in Acapulco have been facing problems with corrupt local police who steal money by extortion and intimidate visitors with threats of jail.The city is divided into three tourist areas.
Traditional Acapulco is the old part of the port, where hotels like Hotel Los Flamingos, owned by personalities Johnny Weissmuller and John Wayne are located, is on the northern end of the bay. Anchored by attractions such as the beaches of Caleta and Caletilla, the cliff divers of La Quebrada, and the city square, known as El Zocalo.  The heyday of this part of Acapulco ran from the late 1930s until the 1960s, with development continuing through the 1980s. This older section of town now caters to a mostly middle-class, almost exclusively Mexican clientele, while the glitzier newer section caters to the Mexican upper classes, many of whom never venture into the older, traditional part of town.Acapulco Dorado had its development between the 1950s and the 1970s, and is about 25 minutes from the Acapulco International Airport. It is the area that presents the most tourist influx in the port, runs through much of the Acapulco bay, from Icacos, passing through Costera Miguel Aleman Avenue, which is the main one, to Papagayo Park. It has several hotels,
Acapulco Diamante, also known as Punta Diamante, is the newest and most developed part of the port, with investment having created one of the greatest concentrations of luxury facilities in Mexico, including exclusive hotels and resorts of international chains, residential complexes, luxury condominiums and private villas, spas, restaurants, shopping areas and a golf course. Starting at the Scenic Highway in Las Brisas, it includes Puerto Marqués and Punta Diamante and extends to Barra Vieja Beach. It is 10 minutes from the Acapulco International Airport. In this area, all along Boulevard de las Naciones, almost all transportation is by car, limousine or golf cart.Acapulco's reputation of a high-energy party town and the nightlife have long been draws of the city for tourists. From November to April, luxury liners stop here daily and include ships such as the MS Queen Victoria, the MS Rotterdam, Crystal Harmony, and all the Princess line ships. Despite Acapulco's international fame, most of its visitors are from central Mexico, especially the affluent from Mexico City. Acapulco is one of the embarkation ports for the Mexican cruise line Ocean Star Cruises.For the Christmas season of 2009, Acapulco received 470,000 visitors, most of whom are Mexican nationals, adding 785 million pesos to the economy. Eighty percent arrive by land and eighteen percent by air. The area has over 25,000 condominiums, most of which function as second homes for their Mexican owners. Acapulco is still popular with Mexican celebrities and the wealthy, such as Luis Miguel and Plácido Domingo, who maintain homes there.


==== Problems ====
While much of the glitz and glamour that made Acapulco famous still remains, from the latter 20th century on, the city has also taken on other less-positive reputations. Some consider it a passé resort, eclipsed by the newer Cancún and Cabo San Lucas. Over the years, a number of problems have developed here, especially in the bay and the older sections of the city. The large number of wandering vendors on the beaches, who offer everything from newspapers to massages, are a recognized problem. It is a bother to tourists who simply want to relax on the beach, but the government says it is difficult to eradicate, as there is a lot of unemployment and poverty here. Around the city are many small shantytowns that cling to the mountainsides, populated by migrants who have come here looking for work. In the last decade, drug-related violence has caused massive problems for the local tourism trade.
Another problem is the garbage that has accumulated in the bay. Although 60.65 tons have recently been extracted from the bays of Acapulco and nearby Zihuatanejo, more needs to be done. Most of trash removal during the off seasons is done on the beaches and in the waters closest to them. However, the center of the bay is not touched. The reason trash winds up in the bay is that it is common here to throw it in streets, rivers and the bay itself. The most common items cleaned out of the bay are beer bottles and car tires.  Acapulco has seen some success in this area, having several beaches receiving the high "blue flag" certifications for cleanliness and water quality.


=== Gastronomy ===
Acapulco's gastronomy is very rich. The following are typical dishes from the region:
Relleno is baked pork with a variety of vegetables and fruits such as potatoes, raisins, carrots and chiles. It is eaten with bread called bolillo.
Pozole is a soup with a salsa base (it can be white, red or green), corn, meat that can be either pork or chicken and it is accompanied with antojitos (snacks) like tostadas, tacos and tamales. This dish is served as part of a weekly Thursday event in the city and the state, with many restaurants offering the meal with special entertainment, from bands to dancers to celebrity impersonators.


=== Attractions ===

Acapulco's main attraction is its nightlife, as it has been for many decades. Nightclubs change names and owners frequently.
For example, Baby 'O has been open to the national and international public since 1976 and different celebrities have visited their installations such as Mexican singer Luis Miguel, Bono from U2 and Sylvester Stallone. Another nightclub is Palladium, located in the Escénica Avenue, the location gives the nightclub a beautiful view of the Santa Lucia Bay at night. Various DJs have had performances in Palladium among them DVBBS, Tom Swoon, Nervo and Junkie KID.Informal lobby or poolside cocktail bars often offer free live entertainment. In addition, there is the beach bar zone, where younger crowds go. These are located along the Costera road, face the ocean and feature techno or alternative rock. Most are concentrated between the Fiesta Americana and Continental Plaza hotels. These places tend to open earlier and have more informal dress. There is a bungee jump in this area as well.

Another attraction at Acapulco is the La Quebrada Cliff Divers. The tradition started in the 1930s when young men casually competed against each other to see who could dive from the highest point into the sea below. Eventually, locals began to ask for tips for those coming to see the men dive. Today the divers are professionals, diving from heights of forty metres (130 feet) into an inlet that is only seven m (23 ft) wide and four m (13 ft) deep, after praying first at a shrine to the Virgin of Guadalupe. On December 12, the feast day of this Virgin, freestyle cliff divers jump into the sea to honor her. Dives range from the simple to the complicated and end with the "Ocean of Fire" when the sea is lit with gasoline, making a circle of flames which the diver aims for. The spectacle can be seen from a public area which charges a small fee or from the Hotel Plaza Las Glorias/El Mirador from its bar or restaurant terrace.There are a number of beaches in the Acapulco Bay and the immediate coastline. In the bay proper there are the La Angosta (in the Quebrada), Caleta, Caletilla, Dominguillo, Tlacopanocha, Hornos, Hornitos, Honda, Tamarindo, Condesa, Guitarrón, Icacos, Playuela, Playuelilla and Playa del Secreto. In the adjoining, smaller Bay of Puerto Marqués there is Pichilingue, Las Brisas, and Playa Roqueta. Facing open ocean just northwest of the bays is Pie de la Cuesta and southeast are Playa Revolcadero, Playa Aeromar, Playa Encantada and Barra Vieja. Two lagoons are in the area, Coyuca to the northwest of Acapulco Bay and Tres Palos to the southeast. Both lagoons have mangroves and offer boat tours. Tres Palos also has sea turtle nesting areas which are protected.In addition to sunbathing, the beaches around the bay offer a number of services, such as boat rentals, boat tours, horseback riding, scuba diving and other aquatic sports. One popular cruise is from Caletilla Beach to Roqueta Island, which has places to snorkel, have lunch, and a lighthouse. There is also an underwater statue of the Virgin of Guadalupe here, created in 1958 by Armando Quesado in memory of a group of divers who died here. Many of the scuba-diving tours come to this area as well, where there are sunken ships, sea mountains, and cave rock formations. Another popular activity is deep-sea fishing. The major attraction is sail fishing. Fish caught here have weighed between 89 and 200 pounds. Sailfish are so plentiful that boat captains have been known to bet with a potential customer that if he does not catch anything, the trip is free.In the old part of the city, there is a traditional main square called the Zócalo, lined with shade trees, cafés and shops. At the north end of the square is Nuestra Señora de la Soledad cathedral, with blue onion-shaped domes and Byzantine towers. The building was originally constructed as a movie set, but was later adapted into a church. Acapulco's most historic building is the Fort of San Diego, located east of the main square and originally built in 1616 to protect the city from pirate attacks. The fort was partially destroyed by the Dutch in the mid-17th century, rebuilt, then destroyed again in 1776 by an earthquake. It was rebuilt again by 1783 and this is the building that can be seen today, unchanged except for renovations done to it in 2000. Parts of the moats remain as well as the five bulwarks and the battlements. Today the fort serves as the Museo Histórico de Acapulco (Acapulco Historical Museum), which shows the port's history from the pre-Hispanic period until independence. There are temporary exhibits as well. For many years tourists could ride around the city in colorful horse-drawn carriages known as calandrias, but the practice ended in February 2020 due to concerns about mistreatment of the animals.

The El Rollo Acapulco is a sea-life and aquatic park located on Costera Miguel Aleman. It offers wave pools, water slides and water toboggans. There are also dolphin shows daily and a swim with dolphins program. The center mostly caters to children. Another place that is popular with children is the Parque Papagayo: a large family park which has a life-sized replica of a Spanish galleon, three artificial lakes, an aviary, a skating rink, rides, go-karts and more.The Dolores Olmedo House is located in the traditional downtown of Acapulco and is noted for the murals by Diego Rivera that adorn it. Olmedo and Rivera had been friend since Olmedo was a child and Rivera spent the last two years of his life here. During that time, he painted nearly nonstop and created the outside walls with tile mosaics, featuring Aztec deities such as Quetzalcoatl. The interior of the home is covered in murals. The home is not a museum, so only the outside murals can be seen by the public.There is a small museum called Casa de la Máscara (House of Masks) which is dedicated to masks, most of them from Mexico, but there are examples from many parts of the world. The collection contains about one thousand examples and is divided into seven rooms called Masks of the World, Mexico across History, The Huichols and the Jaguar, Alebrijes, Dances of Guerrero, Devils and Death, Identity and Fantasy, and Afro-Indian masks.
The Botanical Garden of Acapulco is a tropical garden located on lands owned by the Universidad Loyola del Pacífico. Most of the plants here are native to the region, and many, such as the Peltogyne mexicana or purple stick tree, are in danger of extinction.One cultural event that is held yearly in Acapulco is the Festival Internacional de la Nao, which takes place in the Fort of San Diego, located near the Zócalo in downtown of the city. The Festival honors the remembrance of the city's interaction and trades with Oriental territories which started back in the Sixteenth Century. The Nao Festival consists of cultural activities with the support of organizations and embassies from India, China, Japan, Philippines, Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea. The variety of events go from film projections, musical interpretations and theatre to gastronomical classes, some of the events are specifically for kids.The annual French Festival takes place throughout Acapulco city and offers a multitude of events that cement cultural links between Mexico and France. The main features are a fashion show and a gourmet food fair. The Cinépolis Galerías Diana and the Teatro Juan Ruíz de Alarcón present French and French literary figures who give talks on their specialised subjects. Even some of the local nightclubs feature French DJs. Other festivals celebrated here include Carnival, the feast of San Isidro Labrador on 15 May, and in November, a crafts and livestock fair called the Nao de China.There are a number of golf courses in Acapulco including the Acapulco Princess and the Pierre Marqués course, the latter designed by Robert Trent Jones in 1972 for the World Cup Golf Tournament. The Mayan Palace course was designed by Pedro Guericia and an economical course called the Club de Golf Acapulco is near the convention center. The most exclusive course is that of the Tres Vidas Golf Club, designed by Robert von Hagge. It is located next to the ocean and is home to flocks of ducks and other birds.Another famous sport tournament that has been held in Acapulco since 1993 is the Abierto Mexicano Telcel tennis tournament, an ATP 500 event that takes place in the tennis courts of the Princess Mundo Imperial, a resort located in the Diamante zone of Acapulco. Initially it was played in clay courts but it changed to hard court. The event has gained popularity within the passing of the years, attracting some of the top tennis players in the world including Novak Djokovic, Rafael Nadal and Marin Cilic. The total prize money is US$250,000.00 for WTA (women) and US$1,200,000.00 for ATP (men).Acapulco also has a bullring, called the Plaza de Toros, near Caletilla Beach. The season runs during the winter and is called the Fiesta Brava.


=== Spring break ===
Before 2010, over 100,000 American teenagers and young adults traveled to resort areas and balnearios throughout Mexico during spring break each year. The main reason students head to Mexico is the drinking age of 18 years (versus 21 for the United States), something that has been marketed by tour operators along with the sun and ocean. This has become attractive since the 1990s, especially since more traditional spring break places such as Daytona Beach, Florida, have enacted restrictions on drinking and other behaviors. This legislation has pushed spring break tourism to various parts of Mexico, with Acapulco as one of the top destinations.In the late 1990s and early 2000s, Cancún had been favored as the spring break destination of choice. However, Cancún has taken some steps to control the reckless behavior associated with the event, and students have been looking for someplace new. This led many more to choose Acapulco, in spite of the fact that for many travelers, the flight is longer and more expensive than to Cancún. Many were attracted by the glitzy hotels on the south side and Acapulco's famous nightlife. In 2008, 22,500 students came to Acapulco for spring break. Hotels did not get that many in 2009, due mostly to the economic situation in the United States, and partially because of scares of drug-related violence.In February 2009, the US State Department issued a travel alert directed at college students planning spring break trips to Acapulco. The warning—a result of violent activity springing from Mexico's drug cartel débâcle—took college campuses by storm, with some schools going so far as to warn their students about the risks of travel to Mexico over spring break. Bill O'Reilly devoted a segment of his show, The O'Reilly Factor, to urge students to stay away from Acapulco. In June 2009, a number of incidents occurred between the drug cartel and the government. These included coordinated attacks on police headquarters and open battles in the streets, involving large-caliber weapons and grenades. However, no incidents of violence against travelers on spring break were reported.


== Transportation ==

Many airlines fly to Acapulco International Airport. In the city, there are many buses and taxi services one can take to get from place to place, but most of the locals choose to walk to their destinations. However, an important mode of transportation is the government-subsidized 'Colectivo' cab system. These cabs cost 13 pesos per person to ride, but they are not private. The driver will pick up more passengers as long as seats are available, and will transport them to their destination based on first-come, first-served rules. The colectivos each travel a designated area of the city, the three main ones being Costera, Colosio, Coloso, or a mixture of the three. Coloso cabs travel mainly to old Acapulco. Colosio cabs travel through most of the tourist area of Acapulco. Costera cabs drive up and down the coast of Acapulco, where most of the hotels for visitors are located, but which includes some of old Acapulco. Where a driver will take you is partly his choice. Some are willing to travel to the other designated areas, especially during slow periods of the day.
The bus system is highly complex and can be rather confusing to an outsider. As far as transportation goes, it is the cheapest form, other than walking, in Acapulco. The most expensive buses have air conditioning, while the cheaper buses do not. For tourists, the Acapulco city government has established a system of yellow buses with Acapulco painted on the side of them. These buses are not for tourists only, but are certainly the nicest and most uniform of the bus systems. These buses travel the tourist section of Acapulco, driving up and down the coast. There are buses with specific routes and destinations, generally written on their windshields or shouted out by a barker riding in the front seat. Perhaps the most unusual thing about the privately operated buses is the fact that they are all highly decorated and personalized, with decals and home-made interior designs that range from comic book scenes, to pornography, and even to "Hello Kitty" themes.The conflictive public transportation would be upgraded the 25th of June 2016 with the implementation of the Acabus. The Acabus infrastructure has a length of 36.2 kilometres (22.5 miles), counts with 16 stations that spread through the city of Acapulco and 5 routes. This project will help organize traffic because the buses now have a specific line on the roads and there would be more control over transportation and passengers.
